title: When will a new Dutch government be sworn in after the 2021 general election?
preds:
https://nltimes.nl/2021/09/07/d66-leader-kaag-criticizes-rutte-annual-lecture TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 7, 2021 
"D66 leader Sigrid Kaag gave the annual H.J. Schoo-lecture on Monday evening, in which she expressed her displeasure the formation process stalling over right-wing unwillingness to work with left-wing parties. Without explicitly naming him, she criticized caretaker Prime Minister Mark Rutte and the VVD, NOS reports.
. . . 
Kaag also spoke about the cabinet formation process, which has been dragging on for nearly six months since the parliamentary election on March 17. Kaag said that it is "difficult for her to comprehend" why the formation attempt with left-wing parties GroenLinks and PvdA failed.  . . .  In the summer, the VVD and D66 as the largest two parties wrote an outline that was to form the basis of a coalition agreement, with the idea that other parties could join the coalition based on its content. PvdA and GroenLinks reacted positively to the content, but the VVD and CDA insisted that they don't want to govern with both left-wing parties. Even after GroenLinks and PvdA offered to join the negotiations as one bloc, instead of as two separate parties. According to Kaag, potential allies where therefore excluded on grounds other than content. "The level of The Hague commotion in this formation is much too high. More time seems to be spent on what is written in the newspaper than the history we want to write ourselves. I don't feel comfortable with that," Kaag said. Former formation informateur Mariette Hamer made similar points when she presented the report on her failed attempt to find a majority coalition. Kaag said that it is now up to the six parties involved - VVD, D66, CDA, GroenLinks, PvdA, and ChristenUnie - to come up with a solution together. "A good cabinet in the Dutch tradition is a cabinet that consists of conservative and progressive forces. So a balanced cabinet," she said. As the largest party, the VVD has "the responsibility to regain substantive support and political confidence, especially from the left," she added. The new informateur, Johan Remkes, will start investigating the possibilities for a minority government later this week. Kaag said that her party is willing to talk, but only under clear conditions, including actually tackling the climate crisis. "It is the precondition for everything else. You will understand that I cannot be a credible part of a cabinet that does not deploy a dramatic and ultimate acceleration of the Dutch climate policy." ~~~~~~
COMMENT:  Thanks for this link goes to @fisherdbus @https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1333630.  
I am having a hard time imagining a "marriage" of Rutte & Kaag after all the public dissing.  It has to happen, but I don't think it will be happy, stable, or long-lasting.
At this point in time, there is no indication that a government will be sworn in by the end of the week.

https://www.dutchnews.nl/news/2021/09/coalition-fixer-remkes-tells-parties-to-focus-on-urgent-problems/ "September 9, 2021  Veteran political fixer Johan Remkes has told the parties in the stalled coalition talks to bury their differences and build a working minority coalition. The 70-year-old former VVD home affairs minister took over from Labour politician Mariëtte Hamer this week as the talks moved into the cabinet formation stage. Remkes has given himself a month to try to forge a minority coalition . . .  he warned he would not stand for parties continuing to rule each other out as potential partners, after VVD and CDA rejected a five-way coalition with two left-wing parties while D66 refused to team up again with the ChristenUnie (CU). ‘If they stick with that attitude I’ll be done with it very quickly,’ Remkes said on Wednesday after meeting the three core parties.  "On Thursday he will sit down with the leaders of CU, Labour (PvdA) and GroenLinks, the other participants in Hamer’s exploratory talks over the summer. ‘It is up to the parties themselves to come out of this impasse,’ he said. ‘The mutual relationships need to grow.’ He said the talks needed to focus on substance rather than political strategy, ‘because there are urgent problems that are asking for a solution.’ "GroenLinks leader Jesse Klaver said his party would not get involved in behind-the-scenes discussions to support a minority cabinet. 
. . .
[To summarize:]  "VVD leader and caretaker prime minister Mark Rutte rejected a five-party coalition with PvdA and GroenLinks as ‘unstable’, . . . argued that only one of the parties was needed for a majority cabinet, but their leaders were only prepared to go into government as a duo. Rutte’s preference for a cabinet with the CU was blocked by D66 leader Sigrid Kaag because of the two parties’ fundamental difference on issues such as euthanasia and abortion rights. A cabinet of VVD, D66 and CDA would have 72 seats, four short of a majority, meaning either CU, GroenLinks, PvdA or the nationalist right-wing JA21 could supply the votes it needs to get its legislation through the Lower House. However, Kaag is likely to have reservations about brokering a coalition deal with two conservative parties who have very different positions on issues including migration, Europe and welfare spending."
~~~~~
COMMENT:  It sounds like Remkes is a tough, no-nonsense negotiator, and he may be making progress, but he's got some hard nuts to crack.  I just don't see everything coming together in less than a week.
Running out of runway on the time factor

https://www.lalibre.be/international/europe/2021/09/08/negociations-politiques-aux-pays-bas-une-coalition-minoritaire-envisagee-HVM3DXRB6NCQJIMQKARD2LMBNM/ "After a long debate, the Dutch parliament on Tuesday backed a proposal allowing Remkes to explore the possibilities of forming a minority government. The new informant believes that the success of his mission is not guaranteed and that the way out of the political impasse depends on the parties. He did not set a deadline "but during the month of October a lot of things should become clearer".
~~~~
COMMENT:  I note he said, ". . . during the month of October . . ."  That's what the Dutch consul general in SF also told me.

https://nltimes.nl/2021/09/08/parliament-supports-looking-minority-coalition-cabinet-formation ". . . On Tuesday, parliament debated with informateur Mariette Hamer about her final report. According to her, forming a majority coalition currently seems impossible and a minority coalition consisting of a "to be determined combination of VVD, D66, and CDA" should be considered. Hamer did not sound very optimistic about the chances of her liberal successor. According to her, it will be even more complicated to form a  minority cabinet under the current circumstances, she told the parliamentarians. More than five months after the elections, the formation is deadlocked. VVD leader Mark Rutte repeated that he did not want to enter into negotiations with GroenLinks and PvdA about the formation of a new government. The CDA is against that too. D66 does not want to continue in the current coalition of VVD, CDA, D66 and ChristenUnie. A speech by Kaag a day before the debate with implicit criticism of Rutte will not make Remkes' task any easier. "
~~~~~~~
COMMENT: I find little in this to suggest that a resolution will be achieved in the next 9 days. EDIT:  Additional link:  https://www.dutchnews.nl/news/2021/09/the-netherlands-heads-for-a-minority-cabinet-as-coalition-talks-resume/

https://www.ad.nl/politiek/weinig-warmte-tussen-rutte-en-kaag-remkes-moet-minderheidskabinet-smeden~a394e8b6/ Article mentions there is little warmth between 2 main party leaders, who need to create a minority government. THat's a big task to complete in next 10 days...too big one like my self might argue

Thanks to @keith-huggins' link at  @-https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1330172  My takeaway from that article is: 
"Talks to form the next Dutch government are expected to continue for weeks." My thinking is that Rutte is not in a hurry to form such a government because passing legislation as a minority government won't be easy. He'll have to scramble for votes to sell every piece. HOWEVER, the Dutch ambassador told me that if Rutte & Kaag DO decide to form a minority government, it could come together "quite quickly". What's "quite quickly"? 10 days or less?? There's 10 days until this question closes! I'm going to be keeping an eye out for more statements about a plan to form a minority government!

It is now more than 5 months after the election. Two key parties do not to form an administration with leftist parties. (And this in a fairly left-wing country) There appears to be lack of will to compromise. I assume the country has evolved with stable institutions that can carry on without the Government. It just means that no new laws are passed. https://www.euronews.com/2021/08/31/dutch-coalition-talks-deadlocked-5-months-after-election
They learned from Belgium that a political government is not required for long periods.

17 days to go and the various parties are still bickering like children in a playground after an election held 24 weeks ago; https://bit.ly/3jBGdXW. Little likelihood of much happening in 17 days with the exception of a minority government of VVD, D66 & CDA. Hence a 0% rating for the time being in bucket 2. Some more background: https://bit.ly/38tjWFj / https://bit.ly/3jBGdXW / https://bit.ly/3t5ULBU  @Anneinak / @MCowley / @SE_Meyer
The latest breakdown in talks and the pairing of the Green and Labour parties make the likelihood of a 5 party coalition very unlikely
They have run out of time if my previous assumptions about the length of time for swearing in are correct.

Decreasing on the news that talks are still deadlocked and a deal doesn't seem reachable anytime soon. Source: https://www.euronews.com/2021/08/31/dutch-coalition-talks-deadlocked-5-months-after-election
Further delays, although the end seems to be in sight

https://nltimes.nl/2021/08/26/less-market-control-housing-healthcare-planned-draft-coalition-agreement-report Less market control on housing, healthcare planned in draft coalition agreement between WD & D66. "Other proposals in in the draft agreement make it seem aimed at cooperation with the left-wing parties, rather than ChristenUnie.
. . . 
"Informateur Mariette Hamer asked VVD leader Mark Rutte and D66 leader Sigrid Kaag, as the leaders of the two largest parties after the parliamentary elections in March, to draw up this draft document in an attempt to convince other parties to join a coalition based on content. The fact that the CDA will be in the next coalition already seems a foregone conclusion - the VVD and CDA have both been vocal in their determination to keep working together. But at least one more party is needed for a majority in parliament. "The candidates for that party is ChristenUnie, and left-wing parties PvdA, and GroenLinks. The two left-wing parties are determined to only join a cabinet together, so that the left-wing plans don't disappear under those of right-wing duo VVD and CDA. "And based on the plans that leaked from the draft coalition agreement, it seems that the VVD and D66 are also aiming for a coalition with the left-wing parties, despite VVD and CDA reluctance to work with both parties. Especially the plan to give people control over the end of their lives suggests this. The D66 has been championing a legislative proposal to allow euthanasia at the end of a complete life, while the ChristenUnie blocked that from happening in the current Rutte III coalition. The embryo law will also be a sticking point for the conservative Christian party. Kaag also recently reiterated that the D66 isn't enthusiastic about working with the ChristenUnie again.  "Last week it was expected that informateur Hamer would recommend a potential coalition to start formation negotiations sometime this week. Now it seems that she's waiting on GroenLinks and PvdA member consultations happening on Saturday, regarding the parties' proposal to join the negotiations as a single bloc. The outcome of the PvdA consultation in particular will be exciting, as some members are still smarting from the major losses the PvdA suffered after the Rutte II VVD-PvdA coalition.
~~~~~
COMMENT:  So, 
1) something has been happening!  
2) but it has been a slower process than anticipated even as recently as last week
3) The PvdA consultation which went on today may move things along, or not!
I think that even if they were in a hurry, they don't have time before this question closes.   See @https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1325299 by @PhilosophyWombat.

There is little time left before 18 September, there is still no agreement between D66 and VVD about who their preferred coalition parties would be and official negotiations have not even started. After formal negotiations between parties start they still need to write a 'regeerakkoord' decide who the cabinet will be and get approved by the party members of the parties within the coalition (which will be 4 or 5 parties). Last time this process took 3 months (june 24 till oktober 26), it seems really unlikely it will take less than 4 weeks this time.

The merger of the two left-wing blocs is progress. https://www.dutchnews.nl/news/2021/08/left-wing-bloc-could-break-coalition-negotiations-impasse/ Still, it's not clear that three weeks is enough time.

This article came to my attention thanks to @Emking
https://nltimes.nl/2021/08/16/vvd-d66-excited-start-formation-talks-parties It has a very optimistic tone.  Perhaps I've been too cynical, pessimistic and jaded.   Increasing forecast for current time period from 10 to 30%.

@V-Y-   @https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1319689 Thanks for the link!!!!!  Google translate is a wonderful thing!  I was able to translate it 2 paragraphs at a time, no problem.
https://eenvandaag.avrotros.nl/item/oud-kamervoorzitter-weisglas-wil-nieuwe-verkiezingen-als-formatie-niet-opschiet/ What I got out of the article (besides what you mentioned) is:
-the writer called the current delay in government formation "shocking" and "embarrassing".  Where was he 4 yrs ago when it took Rutte until early November to form a new government?   "Shocking" doesn't seem to me to be an apt adjective because this is not unprecedented.  Rutte has to work with the cards that the electorate dealt him:  a very splintered election result, split between parties that do not want to work together.  It's not particularly "embarrassing", either, given that it took Merkel how many months to form her current coalition?  and Italy has had how many governments in the last 4 years?   -The writer is clamoring for a new election.   How well did that work in Israel?  How many times did they have new elections in Israel which produced such splintered results that they were unable to form a new government?  3?   Why would Rutte do this?   BESIDES, if new elections will be called, then this question will DEFINITELY resolve as "not before 18 Sept 2021". -One thing the writer mentioned that might make a difference/get things going & resolved sooner is if there is a new "formateur"/lead negotiator selected who is not from one of 2 largest parties.. . . someone other than Rutte (been there/done that, not liked), Kaag (not liked) or Hammer (not perceived as neutral, weak?). . . Is anyone asking for this besides him? So, the questions I have are:
-is/are there some policy issue(s) that is/are pressing that the public/parliament want addressed?  Is this creating pressure on Rutte?
-what is the mood of parliament?  Is it getting antsy? 
-where's public opinion on this?  is the public starting to agitate for a resolution to the situation?
-is Von der Heiden just one of those people who needs to see his name in the headlines every so often?   I'm increasing my forecast for "not before 18 Sept" just in case his thinking prevails and rather than form a new government, the decision is made to call a new election. Caveat:  I haven't yet read @Emking  link at @https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1320168
Holding back a little until next week, as talks resume. https://netherlandsnewslive.com/coalition-negotiations-resume-on-monday-meeting-kerg-rutte-and-hummer/217961/

I'm already late on this question, but as I was reading a bit I noticed some peculiarity of Dutch system and recent trends in their political landscape.   => so I'm going with the crowd, but putting more weight towards those who are more familiar with the matter, and simply trimming the final estimates.  https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20210709-dutch-politics-deadlocked-as-small-parties-proliferate [July 9, 2021]
1) The proliferation of small parties and the absence of an electoral threshold inevitably lead to long periods of negotiation which could end in a stalemate and even fresh polls, analysts say.
This is precisely __the Gordian knot__ that awaits Rutte IV. 2) The splintering of traditional political parties is not unique to the Netherlands and has spread to other European countries, a phenomenon analysts call the "Dutchification" of politics. # ================== also thanks to @V-Y- [ https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1319689 ]

Tweaking down  probabilities for fast closure Prominent Old Guard - member of the same party as PM- wrote opinion piece arguing to call another election if they cannot agree to a new government by Oct. If that's the deadline, the pressure to do so mid-September (1 week before the new budget presentation) is minimal Sorry in Dutch https://eenvandaag.avrotros.nl/item/oud-kamervoorzitter-weisglas-wil-nieuwe-verkiezingen-als-formatie-niet-opschiet/

Today, I met 4 Dutch citizens, including the Ambassador to the US and the Consul-General in San Francisco.   I learned:
-that a provisional/caretaker government can govern until the next election!
-that a provisional/caretaker government cannot change policy or adopt new policies . . . about, say, climate change or COVID
-that some think that there is a very slim chance that Rutte & Kaag will agree to form a minority government.  If this happens, it could be done in short order.
-that, otherwise, it is thought that it will be late September or early October before a new government is sworn in. Consequently, I'm increasing my forecast for after Sept 18th. @bh4eh, @tarun_b, @SE_Meyer, @JMR2017

Very little new on the formation since the end of June (1). There is probably a lot of deal making going behind the scenes but its hard to gauge if its leading to anything.  I expect a new government after 18 September but wouldn't rule out a surprise.  1:

Didn’t account for summer recess and decision maker holidays.
Available time left vs progress adjustment.
I'm not finding any tangible signs of progress over the last month or so and there is no obvious coalition combination yet that is showing signs that it could work.  So moving towards September

I have several different Google Alerts set up on this question.  I am amazed by how seldom any of them produce any hits.  I know that the negotiations are supposed to be secret, but secrets sell newspapers, so since nothing is appearing in the media, nothing must really be happening.   I admit that I see little incentive for Rutte or anyone else to move the negotiations along.   The only thing of significance, reported here by @Mark_T @ https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1312691, to have happened is that the Dutch Parliament reconvened in the middle of its recess because of COVID. . .

Dutch Parliament summer recess dates 3 July 21 to 31 August 21, noting that they were recalled two weeks ago due to rise in COVID cases [1]. With COVID the priority for the current admin, and with no obvious incentive to go fast (I.e. to give up recess time to resolve power sharing) post Sept 18th seems the far more likely bet. [1] https://www.dpa-international.com/topic/dutch-parliament-interrupts-summer-recess-rising-infections-urn%3Anewsml%3Adpa.com%3A20090101%3A210710-99-334352

Passage of time adjustment supported by summer holidays that started 9 July and lasts until mid-August (https://bit.ly/374KRpW), recent cabinet shuffles (https://bit.ly/2ULu09k), new storm warnings (https://bit.ly/2TxAhoo), increasing Covid-19 hospital cases and disruptions resulting from recent extensive flooding in parts of Netherlands, the move to a new building for parliamentary sittings (https://bit.ly/374KRpW) and the apparent lack of progress reported by the informateur, Harme (https://bit.ly/2ULu09k) after a meeting with the King two weeks ago. All in all, many things to keep people too busy to be concerned about forming a government, while Rutte probably has little motivation to progress the formation as he's already in the top job! @Anneinak / @SE_Meyer / @MCowley

Negotiations have been postponed until late August, and the fragmented nature of the Dutch government is bound to drag negotiations out. Source: https://news.google.com/articles/CBMiZWh0dHBzOi8vd3d3LmZyYW5jZTI0LmNvbS9lbi9saXZlLW5ld3MvMjAyMTA3MDktZHV0Y2gtcG9saXRpY3MtZGVhZGxvY2tlZC1hcy1zbWFsbC1wYXJ0aWVzLXByb2xpZmVyYXRl0gFlaHR0cHM6Ly9hbXAuZnJhbmNlMjQuY29tL2VuL2xpdmUtbmV3cy8yMDIxMDcwOS1kdXRjaC1wb2xpdGljcy1kZWFkbG9ja2VkLWFzLXNtYWxsLXBhcnRpZXMtcHJvbGlmZXJhdGU?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen
The delay to mid august in reality only leaves two weeks of talks to come up with an agreement.

The recent elections in the Netherlands had offered the largest number of political parties since the 1940’s with a myriad of socio-political agendas in possibly the World’s total proportional representative system that has produced prolonged negotiations with the various factors to formulate a sitting administration. A childcare benefit scandal and issues over political transparency, in the midst of a global pandemic have deadlocked the process. All parties have agreed to further stall talks until mid-August when a draft proposal will be offered by Rutte and the leader of the second largest party.
A firm date before September looks unlikely, although possible. https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/dutch-coalition-talks-postponed-august-drafting-pact-starts-2021-06-22/  https://globalriskinsights.com/2021/06/the-netherlands-struggles-to-find-political-stability-as-polarisation-increases/
Adjusted for the progress of time

Summer recess and little incentive for the ruling party to find compromises it appears.  The country is running well enough at this moment with a caretaker administration so no real imperative to form a government.

Interesting explanation of "Dutchification", and why it may take a long time to form a new government: https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20210709-dutch-politics-deadlocked-as-small-parties-proliferate After the summer break, in mid-August, the search continues. Whether a government will be in place from then until 18 September in about a month's time is becoming increasingly unlikely.
Update because of the passage of time without visible progress
I don’t like the current one. For very specific reasons!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
The more I think about this situation, the more it seems to me that Rutte has no incentive(s) to move negotiations along.  They're on break now; who works on thorny negotiations while on break?
Talks are still deadlocked, few signs of progress or a workable solution so moving towards the third bin
The deadlock drags on with talks expected to resume in mid-August.
The Dutch parliament are now on recess until the 5th of September. I am not suggesting no negotiations will occur during that time, but rather that there may not be much urgency.
Passed the deadline for the first option
As @Anneinak pointed out, https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1298440, Rutte has little incentive to make any effort to get a coalition in place soon. @SE_Meyer

~~~~~ https://www.dutchnews.nl/news/2021/06/vvd-and-d66-to-start-sketching-out-a-coalition-deal-as-impasse-continues/ "The leaders of the two biggest parties will start putting an agreement down on paper at the suggestion of coalition negotiator Mariette Hamer, who said on Tuesday that by mid August, the parties prepared to form a new coalition government must be involved in serious negotiations.  The aim is not to draw up a cut and dried agreement but to see if the other four parties still in the talks agree with the problems and solutions put forward by Kaag and Rutte. COMMENT:  The thought just occurred to me that Rutte doesn't have a lot of incentive to push this along since the coalition he wants is the coalition he has & leads.  Increasing forecast for last period.

Hamers report has just been published (1). Conclusion, a 6 party coalition is currently not possible. Her advice is for VVD and D66 to start a document on main point to which the other parties can be added the second half of august. That leaves 1 month for a coalition to be concluded before 17 September.  1 In Dutch:

But behind the scenes, Mariette Hamer, who has been charged with facilitating the talks, is working on different scenarios to move the process on . . . "Six parties – VVD, D66, CDA, PvdA, GroenLinks and ChristenUnie – remain potential partners and their leaders are due to meet Hamer for joint talks later on Friday.  NOS says there are three options on the table. One involves asking VVD leader Mark Rutte and D66 leader Sigrid Kaag to write a draft coalition agreement, the second would involve giving Rutte the job alone. The sources told NOS they expect Hamer may publish her end report next week, three weeks later than originally planned.

COMMENT:  This actually sounds like progress to me!

The window for a first-bin outcome is closing quickly now.
Hamer is apparently meeting with Hoekstra (CDA) and Segers (CU) for further talks today, which suggests a continuation of the former coalition has become slightly more likely and could be the dominant strategy in the government formation now in order to achieve a quick resolution of a deadlock.
With all the dirt that has come to light (new: https://www.dutchnews.nl/news/2021/06/cda-confirms-publishing-millionaire-gave-e1m-to-election-campaign/ ) and the Omtzigt departure, the CDA lost support dramatically in recent polls and must be happy if they avoid a new election in the first place and if they are included in a new government.
However, unless there's a miracle (see Rutte III cabinet = Rutte IV cabinet) immediately, a new government will not be sworn in before Friday this week. Thus, it looks like a demissionary government will attend the next European Council meeting next week.
With respect to the government formation, Hoekstra and the CDA now must be considered as the most obstructive force, which is consistent with their lost parliamentary weight in the past 2021 election, probably a good deal of miscalculation and loss of reality and their fear of being marginalized in a new government, a factor that I have previously under-estimated.
Lesson learned: be more critical of and constantly question your own assumptions. Two of my baisc assumptions (1. a new government will be needed for the ORD to be approved in parliament; 2. the government formation will be concluded before the June 2021 European Council meeting) have proven false, sadly.

It has taken Dutch MP’s eight weeks since the 2021 election results to appoint a negotiator, Mariëtte Hamer to forge an agreement amongst the seven political parties to form a coalition government. That is two months.
Her remit was to assess which parties basically agree with each other and produce a tentative coalition of politicians to write a draft agreement.
She reported back on June 6 with the following information:
She did not dare to say how long this would take;
She HOPED that things keep going;

*adjustment for time lapsed since last prediction without significant progress*  1) base rate: average duration of formation since 1946 is 94 days. Variation is large (with the last formation going on for 225 days)
2) There are several factors that would indicate a long formation
a) low trust, with high profile debates on whether certain parties are ethically ok with forming a coalition with others and about openness in political culture.
b) a splintering of parliament, with a record number of parties represented, making majority formation tricky
3) but also some factors that would indicate a speedy transition
a) 'demissionary' status of current government
b) the sense of crisis and need for a mandated government
c) indications from several parties that they are not looking to make a fully negotiated coalition contract but instead will roll over significant chunks of policy making to the post-formation phase. All in all, I expect these to balance out. We will therefor base estimates on the base rate, deduce something from the quick option time lapsed since elections without progress, and also deduce something from the long option as the people would not be likely to accept a lengthy formation period given the Covid-policy that needs to be made.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hugo_de_Jonge
up at night, who isn't exactly "missing" 5bn EUR from his budget but instead didn't put too much attention to having a correct paper trail on how and why the money was spent in his department in early 2020. The problem has been known for at least nine months, but became talk of the Netherlands more recently as it is still unresolved and now under scrutiny by the independent government audit office Algemene Rekenkamer

The whole story reminds me of the turbulence in Germany about N95 masks purchased at outrageous prices with public funds in troubled time of March and April 2020, making a few goods traders multi-millionaires and a few MPs or their relatives earn impressive amounts for their service of brokering the contracts (mainly MPs of the so called "Christian" parties in Bavaria and in the Bundestag, CSU and CDU). Following the March 2021 elections, which returned the largest number of parties to the parliament since 1918, the diversity of the elected members makes for difficult negotiations to form a majority government capable of ruling. (https://bit.ly/32oZd2m) Rutte off VVD, the party with the largest polling and Kaag, of the D66 who received the second biggest proportion of votes, seemed to be at odds as to which parties they would respectively accept as coalition parties. Hence, a few stumbling blocks to overcome at the start of the process of finding compromise and agreement on who would be in the coalition. As has been the case in the past, 'scouts' from VVD & D66 were appointed to work on the coalition. The scouts are also referred to as 'negotiators'. Now, nearly a month after the elections, the scouts have had to resign when press photographers exposed the scouts discussion notes which showed that Rutte was apparently trying to sideline a slightly controversial, in his view, opponent, Pieter Omtzigt (CDA). It appears that the only person aware of this was Rutte. This begs the question why Rutte apparently wanted to sideline Omtzigt? Could it be because Omtzigt was effectively the cause of the downfall of Rutte's last coalition  because of his investigation into the child welfare / tax office debacle? Very possibly, IMO. Nonetheless, this led to a vote in parliament on Rutte's suitability. A vote of no confidence would have seen Rutte powerless in the new coalition. As VVD do not have an heir apparent, they clearly had to vote against any vote.  A compromise 'vote of condemnation' was the result. Parliament and more importantly, the public regard for Rutte appears to be diminishing by the day. See https://bit.ly/2QgVbGD Thus, the scouts had to resign and a new scout has been appointed to see if a coalition can be created that would be accepted by all the potential parties thereto. As Rutte's influence and standing is now reduced, I suggest the creation of the coalition will take longer than originally anticipated. Some serious 'horse trading' is likely to take place over a longer period as possible coalition partners are sounded out and common ground found amongst the parties that initially rejected various potential partners. It's interesting that D66 came first in both Amsterdam and Rotterdam, so the liberal left-leaning party's ascend clearly is an urban phenomenon. It's also interesting that even the Netherlands as a rather small, compact nation obviously have a rural - urban, likely old- young divide with respect to politics. This indicates that the D66 will want to play a much more important role in the upcoming government, which rocks the boat a bit, and it's pretty obvious there's no real way around the D66 for the VVD, unless they are about to forge a coalition of eight or so.
On the other hand, D66 is not strong enough to lead a government themselves: even if they could forge a new movement of all other parties (and the one independent candidate) except for VVD, PVV, CDA, FvD and CU, they'd fail a majority with just 71 seats. D66 + CDA and six more parties would sum 77 seats, but even this is rather unrealistic at this point in time.
The most viable solution seems to be a centrist government of VVD (34 seats), CDA (15; both conservative), D66 (24) plus either PvdA (9) or the green GroenLinks (8), which both seem to keep a balance of 2/3 conservative, 1/3 progressive - no hardliners and pragmatism before party politics -, which could in general achieve good results in terms of government projects and even reflect the will of electorate. 
I think it's rather a matter of details now, and 73 seats for the three most heavy weight-parties are a good precondition for a limited ambition of a fourth junior coalition partner that sees the necessity to support this mix of government politics.

During the last 20 elections dating back to 1952 the cabinet has formed within 90 days 11 times (55%), within 182 days 7 times (35%), and twice over 182 days.  I used this as a base rate but moved slightly towards the lower end because a) polling shows we could get a two-party coalition which is likely to take less time to form and b) after the extensive discussions in 2017 some potential blind alleys will be avoided this time.  However even some 2-party coalitions have taken some time to form so there is still some room for uncertainty. Following poll data (https://www.politico.eu/europe-poll-of-polls/netherlands/), it is highly likely that a multi-party coalition needs to be formed with at least four parties given that Rutte will be able to secure largest win and leader of the government. Since the current government coalition may have a slight edge, it is likely that the same coalition will continue their work.
Therefore, I expect deliberations to be long in comparison to other European countries, but shorter than for the last government, since a notion of urgency on account of the COVID-crisis will surely be felt by all actors.  Should the incumbent coalition not be able to secure an edge, either a five-party coalition must be found, a minority government may be formed or new elections will be held. A minority government or five-party coalition will only be an option after lenghty discussions and should take longer than 3 months to form, but less than 6. 
Only if new elections will be necessary, the formation of a government will be after September 18.

The next Dutch General Election will be held on or before March 17th, 2021, which was the required next election, but the current government resigned early as a result of a childcare tax scandal that affected 1000 of Dutch families, punished unecessiarily for claiming childcare expenses or deductions. In polling this scandal has eroded support for the leading governing party VDD. The current coalition (VDD & PvdA, plus allies) only gets a projected 69 seats, 7 short of the the 76 needed to form a goverment. Council on Foreign Relations wrote the following:
"Dutch General Election, March 17. Dutch voters head to the polls next year to elect the 150 members of the Tweede Kamer, the lower and more powerful of the country’s two legislative chambers. Prime Minister Mark Rutte and his People’s Party for Freedom and Democracy (VVD) have been in power for ten years and are expected to have another strong showing. The centrist VVD’s coalition partners are currently predicted to lose a few seats. This center-right coalition took a record 208 days to put together in 2017 but lost its narrow majority in both houses in 2019. It will be up against the populist Freedom Party (PVV) and its leader Geert Wilders, who favors taking the Netherlands out of the European Union and closing all mosques. Rutte refused to partner with Wilders after the PVV won the second most seats in parliament in 2017. The recent collapse of another far-right party that did surprisingly well in 2019 midterm elections has solidified Wilders’s claim to the populist right, and the PVV is expected to maintain its second-place status in the Tweede Kamer. Rutte, who could become Europe’s longest-serving leader after Angela Merkel steps down, will likely face another tricky coalition-building process to keep the prime minister’s job."
https://www.cfr.org/blog/ten-elections-watch-2021 In the last 40 years, it has taken on average about 92 days to form a government with a 1 standard deviation of between 40 and 144 days. Since 2003, it has taken on average about 122 days to form a government with a 1 standard deviation of between 60 and 184 days. Depending on how polling proceeds it will likely take a little longer to form a government, given the scandal and current governing coalition lacking 76 projected seats. The current coalition of 5 parties will likely need another party or do what has been unthinkable a VDD-PVV led coalition, but likely only if this drags on like in 2002 when assination and rising right lead to a year of political chaos. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2002_Dutch_general_election The pandemic and vaccination effort will likely have in impact that is yet to be determined. 10. When will a new Dutch government be sworn in after the 2021 general election?
a. Initial assessment Base rate: 2012: After Rutte’s government fell on April 23, 2012 (https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-17811509), it took until November 5 to swear in the new government (https://www.government.nl/latest/news/2012/11/05/rutte-asscber-government-sworn-in ), a period of about six-and-a-half months. However, a period of a little less than two months elapsed between the actual elections and the swearing-in (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Dutch_general_election ).  ~ 2 months 2017:  Election on Mar 15 Gov sworn in Oct 26 ~ 7 months Current Situation: As I see it, it will depend largely on the composition of the new government. The reason negotiations took so long in 2017 was that the base of traditional parties was eroded (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-netherlands-government/new-dutch-government-sworn-in-after-record-negotiations-idUSKBN1CV15D ). The VVD is still popular in the Netherlands and is projected to take almost 30% of the vote, more than twice that of the second-place contender (https://www.reuters.com/article/netherlands-politics/update-5-dutch-government-quits-over-colossal-stain-of-tax-subsidy-scandal-idUSL1N2JQ0Z4 ). So, the negotiations should not take as long as they did in 2017. I’m still giving a little bit of a spread for uncertainty, though.
